title: High Fertility
pointers: Rapid population growth.
Common in developing regions where access to education, healthcare, and family planning may be limited.
Strain on resources such as education, healthcare, and infrastructure.
Challenges in poverty reduction and economic development due to a large dependent population (high child-to-adult ratio).

title: Moderate Fertility
pointers: Slower population growth.
A transitional phase in countries undergoing demographic shifts.
Potential for a demographic dividend if accompanied by economic reforms and investments in education and health.
Gradual improvements in resource availability and socio-economic development.

title: Replacement-Level Fertility
pointers: Stable population size in the absence of migration.
This is the level required to replace the existing population in the long term, accounting for infant and child mortality.
Balanced age distribution.
Sustainability in workforce size and economic productivity.

title: Low Fertility
pointers: Declining population size in the long term without migration.
Common in high-income countries with better access to education, healthcare, and contraception.
Aging population, leading to higher dependency ratios (more elderly relative to the working-age population).
Potential labor shortages and increased pressure on social welfare systems.

title: Extremely Low Fertility
pointers: Severe population decline.
Observed in some developed countries, often linked to economic pressures, gender inequality, or lifestyle changes.
Accelerated population aging.
Risk of economic stagnation and challenges in maintaining pension systems and healthcare for the elderly.
